notes:
1. Definition

The tributary area of a structural member is the portion of the floor, roof, or other surface area that is supported by that member. It is the area from which a beam, girder, or column collects its load.

The concept is based on the assumption that the load on a surface is transferred to the nearest supporting member.

2. One-Way vs. Two-Way Slabs

  • One-Way Slab: A slab supported by beams on two opposite sides. It bends in one direction only. The tributary area for a supporting beam is a rectangle extending halfway to the adjacent beams on either side.
  • Two-Way Slab: A slab supported on all four sides. It bends in two directions. The load is distributed to the four supporting beams based on trapezoidal and triangular tributary areas.

3. Calculating Loads

  • Beams and Girders: The total load on a beam is found by multiplying the uniform area load (e.g., in pounds per square foot, psf) by the tributary area. For a one-way system, the tributary width is the distance halfway to the next beam on each side. The load on the beam is then expressed as a uniform line load (in pounds per linear foot, plf).
    • $$ \text{Line Load (plf)} = \text{Area Load (psf)} \times \text{Tributary Width (ft)} $$
  • Columns: The load on a column is found by multiplying the area load by the column's tributary area. For a regular grid, the tributary area is a rectangle bounded by lines halfway to the adjacent columns in all four directions. The result is a concentrated load on the column.

solvedExamples.question: A floor system has parallel beams spaced 8 feet apart. If the total dead and live load on the floor is 100 psf, what is the uniform line load on a typical interior beam?
solvedExamples.explanation: The tributary width for an interior beam is half the distance to the adjacent beam on each side. So, the tributary width is $(8 \text{ ft} / 2) + (8 \text{ ft} / 2) = 4 + 4 = 8$ ft. The line load on the beam is the area load multiplied by the tributary width: $100 \text{ psf} \times 8 \text{ ft} = 800$ plf (pounds per linear foot).

solvedExamples.question: In a building with columns spaced in a 30 ft by 40 ft grid, what is the tributary area for a typical interior column?
solvedExamples.explanation: The tributary area for an interior column extends halfway to the next column in each direction. If the grid is 30 ft x 40 ft, the tributary area is simply the area of one grid bay. Tributary Area = $30 \text{ ft} \times 40 \text{ ft} = 1200$ sq ft.
